41.verse: The sun has one kind of ·beauty [splendor; glory], the moon has another ·beauty [splendor; glory], and the stars have another. And each star is different in its ·beauty [splendor; glory].

42.verse: It is the same with the dead who are raised to life. ·The body that is “planted” will ruin and decay [It is sown/buried in corruption], but it is raised ·to a life that cannot be destroyed [imperishable; in incorruption].

43.verse: ·When the body is “planted,” it is without honor [It is sown/buried in dishonor], but it is raised in glory. ·When the body is “planted,” it is weak [It is sown/buried in weakness], but ·when it is raised, it is powerful [it is raised in power].

44.verse: ·The body that is “planted” is a physical body [It is sown/buried a natural/physical/soulish body]. ·When it is raised, it is [It is raised] a spiritual body. There is a ·physical [natural; soulish] body, and there is also a spiritual body.

45.verse: [So also] It is written in the Scriptures: “The first man, Adam, became a living ·person [soul; Gen. 2:7].” But the last Adam [Christ] became a spirit that gives life.

46.verse: [But] The spiritual did not come first, but the ·physical [natural; soulish] and then the spiritual.

47.verse: The first man came from the dust of the earth. The second man came from heaven.

48.verse: People who ·belong to the earth [or are of dust] are like the first man of ·earth [dust]. But those people who belong to heaven are like the man of heaven.

49.verse: Just as we ·were made like [have borne the image of] the man of earth, so we will also ·be made like [bear the image of] the man of heaven.

50.verse: I tell you this, brothers and sisters: Flesh and blood cannot ·have a part in [inherit] the kingdom of God. ·Something that will ruin cannot […nor can the perishable/corruptible] ·have a part in something that never ruins [inherit the imperishable/incorruptible].

51.verse: But look! I tell you ·this secret [a mystery; 2:1]: We will not all ·sleep in death [sleep; a euphemism for death], but we will all be changed.

52.verse: It will ·take only a second [happen in a flash]—as quickly as an eye ·blinks [or twinkles]—when the last trumpet sounds. The trumpet will sound, and those who have died will be raised ·to live forever [imperishable; incorruptible], and we will be changed [1 Thess. 4:13–17].

53.verse: [For] This body that ·can be destroyed [is perishable/corruptible] must clothe itself with ·something that can never be destroyed [the imperishable/incorruptible]. And this ·body that dies [mortal] must clothe itself with ·something that can never die [immortality].

54.verse: So when this body that ·can be destroyed [is perishable/corruptible] will clothe itself with that which ·can never be destroyed [is imperishable/incorruptible], and this ·body that dies [mortal] will clothe itself with ·that which can never die [immortality], then this Scripture will ·be made true [come to pass]: “Death is ·destroyed forever [swallowed up] in victory [Is. 25:8].”

55.verse: “[O] Death, where is your victory? Death, where is your ·pain [sting; Hos. 13:14]?”

56.verse: Death’s ·power to hurt [sting] is sin, and the power of sin is the law.

57.verse: But we thank God! He gives us the victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.

58.verse: So my ·dear [beloved] brothers and sisters, stand strong. Do not let anything move you. Always ·give yourselves fully to [excel in] the work of the Lord, because you know that your work in the Lord is ·never wasted [not useless/in vain].

1.verse: The Gift for Other Believers - Now ·I will write about [or concerning your question about; concerning; 7:1; 8:1; 12:1] the collection of money for ·God’s people [the saints; 2 Cor. 8—9; Rom. 15:25–28]. Do the same thing I told the Galatian churches to do [Galatia was a Roman province in present-day central Turkey where Paul started churches on his first missionary journey (Acts 13—14)]:

2.verse: On the first day of every week [Sunday], each one of you should put aside money ·as you have been blessed [or what you can afford; whatever one prospers]. Save it up so you will not have to collect money after I come.

3.verse: When I arrive, I will send ·with letters of introduction whomever you approve [or whomever you authorize with your letters] to take your gift to Jerusalem.

4.verse: And if it seems ·good [appropriate; advisable; or worthwhile] for me to go also, they will go along with me.

5.verse: Paul’s Plans - I will come to you after I go through Macedonia—for I am planning to go through Macedonia [the northern part of present-day Greece; Acts 19:21; 20:1, 2; 2 Cor. 1:15–16].

6.verse: Perhaps I will stay with you for a time or even all winter. Then you can help me on my trip, wherever I go.

7.verse: [For] I do not want to see you now just in passing. I hope to stay a longer time with you if the Lord allows it.

8.verse: But I will stay at Ephesus [a prominent city in the Roman province of Asia, present-day western Turkey; Acts 19] until Pentecost [the Jewish festival held on the fiftieth day after Passover (late spring)],

9.verse: because a ·good opportunity for a great and growing work has been given [great and effective door (of opportunity) has opened up] to me now. And there are many ·people working against me [opponents; adversaries].

10.verse: If Timothy comes to you, see to it that ·he has nothing to fear with you [or you put him at ease; you don’t intimidate him], because he is working for the Lord just as I am.

11.verse: So none of you should treat Timothy ·as unimportant [or with contempt], but ·help [send] him on his trip in peace so that he can come back to me. I am expecting him to come with the ·brothers [other believers].

12.verse: Now about our brother Apollos: I strongly encouraged him to visit you with the other brothers. He did not at all want to come now; he will come when he has the opportunity.

13.verse: Paul Ends His Letter - Be ·alert [watchful; on your guard]. ·Continue strong [Stand firm] in the faith. ·Have courage [or Act like men (ready for battle)], and be strong.

15.verse: You know that the ·family [household] of Stephanas were the ·first believers in [firstfruits of] Achaia [southern Greece] and that they have given themselves to the service of ·God’s people [the saints]. I ask you, brothers and sisters,

16.verse: to ·follow the leading of [or submit to the authority of] people like these and anyone else who ·works and serves with them [or works hard in our common task].

17.verse: I ·am happy [rejoice] that Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus have come. ·You are not here, but they have filled your place [or They have supplied the help you could not].

18.verse: [For] They have refreshed my spirit and yours. You should ·recognize the value of [or give recognition to] people like these.

19.verse: The churches in Asia [the Roman province, in present-day Turkey] send greetings to you. Aquila and Priscilla [Acts 18:2–3, 18, 26] greet you in the Lord, as does the church that meets in their house.

20.verse: All the brothers and sisters here send greetings. Greet each other with a holy kiss.

21.verse: I, Paul, am writing this greeting with my own hand [the rest of the letter was evidently dictated to a scribe, called an amanuensis; see Rom. 16:22].

22.verse: If anyone does not love the Lord, let him be ·separated from God—lost forever [anathema]! ·Come, O Lord [Maranatha; Aramaic phrase meaning either “Our Lord, Come!” or “Our Lord has come”]!

23.verse: The grace of the Lord Jesus be with you.

24.verse: My love be with all of you in Christ Jesus.
